words.def: Alexandrov space a generalization of Riemannian manifolds with upper, lower or integral curvature bounds (the last one works only in dimension 2)
words.name: Alexandrov space

words.def: Arc-wise isometry the same as path isometry.
words.name: Arc-wise isometry

words.def: Autoparallel the same as totally geodesic
words.name: Autoparallel

words.def: Barycenter, see center of mass.
words.name: Barycenter

words.def:
bi-Lipschitz map. A map 
  
    
      
        f

        X
        →
        Y
      
    
    {\displaystyle f:X\to Y}
  
 is called bi-Lipschitz if there are positive constants c and C such that for any x and y in X
words.name: bi-Lipschitz map.

words.def: Busemann function given a ray, γ : [0, ∞)→X, the Busemann function is defined by
words.name: Busemann function

words.def: Cartan–Hadamard theorem is the statement that a connected, simply connected complete Riemannian manifold with non-positive sectional curvature is diffeomorphic to Rn via the exponential map; for metric spaces, the statement that a connected, simply connected complete geodesic metric space with non-positive curvature in the sense of Alexandrov is a (globally) CAT(0) space.
words.name: Cartan–Hadamard theorem

words.def: Cartan extended Einstein's General relativity to Einstein-Cartan theory, using Riemannian-Cartan geometry instead of Riemannian geometry. This extension provides affine torsion, which allows for non-symmetric curvature tensors and the incorporation of spin-orbit coupling.
words.name: Cartan

words.def:
Center of mass. A point q ∈ M is called the center of mass of the points 
  
    
      
        
          p
          
            1
          
        
        ,
        
          p
          
            2
          
        
        ,
        …
        ,
        
          p
          
            k
          
        
      
    
    {\displaystyle p_{1},p_{2},\dots ,p_{k}}
  
 if it is a point of global minimum of the function
words.name: Center of mass

words.def: Conformal map is a map which preserves angles.
words.name: Conformal map

words.def: Conformally flat a M is conformally flat if it is locally conformally equivalent to a Euclidean space, for example standard sphere is conformally flat.
words.name: Conformally flat

words.def:
Conjugate points two points p and q on a geodesic 
  
    
      
        γ
      
    
    {\displaystyle \gamma }
  
 are called conjugate if there is a Jacobi field on 
  
    
      
        γ
      
    
    {\displaystyle \gamma }
  
 which has a zero at p and q.
words.name: Conjugate points

words.def:
Convex function. A function f on a Riemannian manifold is a convex if for any geodesic 
  
    
      
        γ
      
    
    {\displaystyle \gamma }
  
 the function 
  
    
      
        f
        ∘
        γ
      
    
    {\displaystyle f\circ \gamma }
  
 is convex. A function f is called 
  
    
      
        λ
      
    
    {\displaystyle \lambda }
  
-convex if for any geodesic 
  
    
      
        γ
      
    
    {\displaystyle \gamma }
  
 with natural parameter

, the function

        γ
        (
        t

        −
        λ
        
          t
          
            2
          
        
      
    
    {\displaystyle f\circ \gamma (t)-\lambda t^{2}}
  
 is convex.
words.name: Convex function.

words.def: Convex A subset K of a Riemannian manifold M is called convex if for any two points in K there is a shortest path connecting them which lies entirely in K, see also totally convex.
words.name: Convex

words.def: Diameter of a metric space is the supremum of distances between pairs of points.
words.name: Diameter

words.def: Developable surface is a surface isometric to the plane.
words.name: Developable surface

words.def: Dilation of a map between metric spaces is the infimum of numbers L such that the given map is L-Lipschitz.
words.name: Dilation

words.def: Exponential map: Exponential map (Lie theory), Exponential map (Riemannian geometry)
words.name: Exponential map

words.def: First fundamental form for an embedding or immersion is the pullback of the metric tensor.
words.name: First fundamental form

words.def: Geodesic is a curve which locally minimizes distance.
words.name: Geodesic

words.def:
Geodesic flow is a flow on a tangent bundle TM of a manifold M, generated by a vector field whose trajectories are of the form 
  
    
      
        (
        γ
        (
        t
        )
        ,
        
          γ
          ′
        
        (
        t
        )
        )
      
    
    {\displaystyle (\gamma (t),\gamma '(t))}
  
 where 
  
    
      
        γ
      
    
    {\displaystyle \gamma }
  
 is a geodesic.
words.name: Geodesic flow

words.def: Geodesic metric space is a metric space where any two points are the endpoints of a minimizing geodesic.
words.name: Geodesic metric space

words.def: Hadamard space is a complete simply connected space with nonpositive curvature.
words.name: Hadamard space

words.def: Horosphere a level set of Busemann function.
words.name: Horosphere

words.def: Injectivity radius The injectivity radius at a point p of a Riemannian manifold is the largest radius for which the exponential map at p is a diffeomorphism. The injectivity radius of a Riemannian manifold is the infimum of the injectivity radii at all points. See also cut locus.
words.name: Injectivity radius

words.def: For complete manifolds, if the injectivity radius at p is a finite number r, then either there is a geodesic of length 2r which starts and ends at p or there is a point q conjugate to p (see conjugate point above) and on the distance r from p. For a closed Riemannian manifold the injectivity radius is either half the minimal length of a closed geodesic or the minimal distance between conjugate points on a geodesic.
words.name: conjugate point

words.def:
Infranilmanifold Given a simply connected nilpotent Lie group N acting on itself by left multiplication and a finite group of automorphisms F of N one can define an action of the semidirect product 
  
    
      
        N
        ⋊
        F
      
    
    {\displaystyle N\rtimes F}
  
 on N. An orbit space of N by a discrete subgroup of 
  
    
      
        N
        ⋊
        F
      
    
    {\displaystyle N\rtimes F}
  
 which acts freely on N is called an infranilmanifold. An infranilmanifold is finitely covered by a nilmanifold.
words.name: Infranilmanifold

words.def: Isometry is a map which preserves distances.
words.name: Isometry

words.def:
Jacobi field A Jacobi field is a vector field on a geodesic γ which can be obtained on the following way: Take a smooth one parameter family of geodesics 
  
    
      
        
          γ
          
            τ
          
        
      
    
    {\displaystyle \gamma _{\tau }}
  
 with 
  
    
      
        
          γ
          
            0
          
        
        =
        γ
      
    
    {\displaystyle \gamma _{0}=\gamma }
  
, then the Jacobi field is described by
words.name: Jacobi field

words.def: Length metric the same as intrinsic metric.
words.name: Length metric

words.def: Levi-Civita connection is a natural way to differentiate vector fields on Riemannian manifolds.
words.name: Levi-Civita connection

words.def: Lipschitz convergence the convergence defined by Lipschitz metric.
words.name: Lipschitz convergence

words.def: Lipschitz distance between metric spaces is the infimum of numbers r such that there is a bijective bi-Lipschitz map between these spaces with constants exp(-r), exp(r).
words.name: Lipschitz distance

words.def: Logarithmic map is a right inverse of Exponential map.
words.name: Logarithmic map

words.def: Minimal surface is a submanifold with (vector of) mean curvature zero.
words.name: Minimal surface

words.def: Natural parametrization is the parametrization by length.
words.name: Natural parametrization

words.def:
Net. A sub set S of a metric space X is called 
  
    
      
        ϵ
      
    
    {\displaystyle \epsilon }
  
-net if for any point in X there is a point in S on the distance 
  
    
      
        ≤
        ϵ
      
    
    {\displaystyle \leq \epsilon }
  
. This is distinct from topological nets which generalise limits.
words.name: Net

words.def:
Nilmanifold: An element of the minimal set of manifolds which includes a point, and has the following property: any oriented 
  
    
      
        
          S
          
            1
          
        
      
    
    {\displaystyle S^{1}}
  
-bundle over a nilmanifold is a nilmanifold. It also can be defined as a factor of a connected nilpotent Lie group by a lattice.
words.name: Nilmanifold

words.def:
Normal bundle: associated to an imbedding of a manifold M into an ambient Euclidean space 
  
    
      
        
          
            
              R
            
          
          
            N
          
        
      
    
    {\displaystyle {\mathbb {R} }^{N}}
  
, the normal bundle is a vector bundle whose fiber at each point p is the orthogonal complement (in 
  
    
      
        
          
            
              R
            
          
          
            N
          
        
      
    
    {\displaystyle {\mathbb {R} }^{N}}
  
) of the tangent space 
  
    
      
        
          T
          
            p
          
        
        M
      
    
    {\displaystyle T_{p}M}
  
.
words.name: Normal bundle

words.def: Nonexpanding map same as short map
words.name: Nonexpanding map

words.def: Polyhedral space a simplicial complex with a metric such that each simplex with induced metric is isometric to a simplex in Euclidean space.
words.name: Polyhedral space

words.def: Principal curvature is the maximum and minimum normal curvatures at a point on a surface.
words.name: Principal curvature

words.def: Principal direction is the direction of the principal curvatures.
words.name: Principal direction

words.def: Proper metric space is a metric space in which every closed ball is compact. Every proper metric space is complete.
words.name: Proper metric space

words.def:
Quasigeodesic has two meanings; here we give the most common. A map 
  
    
      
        f
        :
        I
        →
        Y
      
    
    {\displaystyle f:I\to Y}
  
 (where 
  
    
      
        I
        ⊆
        
          R
        
      
    
    {\displaystyle I\subseteq \mathbb {R} }
  
 is a subsegment) is called a quasigeodesic if there are constants 
  
    
      
        K
        ≥
        1
      
    
    {\displaystyle K\geq 1}
  
 and 
  
    
      
        C
        ≥
        0
      
    
    {\displaystyle C\geq 0}
  
 such that for every 
  
    
      
        x
        ,
        y
        ∈
        I
      
    
    {\displaystyle x,y\in I}
words.name: Quasigeodesic

words.def:
Quasi-isometry. A map 
  
    
      
        f
        :
        X
        →
        Y
      
    
    {\displaystyle f:X\to Y}
  
 is called a quasi-isometry if there are constants 
  
    
      
        K
        ≥
        1
      
    
    {\displaystyle K\geq 1}
  
 and 
  
    
      
        C
        ≥
        0
      
    
    {\displaystyle C\geq 0}
  
 such that
words.name: Quasi-isometry.

words.def: and every point in Y has distance at most C from some point of f(X). Note that a quasi-isometry is not assumed to be continuous. For example any map between compact metric spaces is a quasi isometry. If there exists a quasi-isometry from X to Y, then X and Y are said to be quasi-isometric.
words.name: quasi-isometric

words.def: Radius of metric space is the infimum of radii of metric balls which contain the space completely.
words.name: Radius

words.def: Radius of convexity at a point p of a Riemannian manifold is the largest radius of a ball which is a convex subset.
words.name: Radius of convexity

words.def: Ray is a one side infinite geodesic which is minimizing on each interval
words.name: Ray

words.def: Riemannian submersion is a map between Riemannian manifolds which is submersion and submetry at the same time.
words.name: Riemannian submersion

words.def: Second fundamental form is a quadratic form on the tangent space of hypersurface, usually denoted by II, an equivalent way to describe the shape operator of a hypersurface,
words.name: Second fundamental form

words.def: Shape operator for a hypersurface M is a linear operator on tangent spaces, Sp: TpM→TpM. If n is a unit normal field to M and v is a tangent vector then
words.name: Shape operator

words.def: Short map is a distance non increasing map.
words.name: Short map

words.def: Sol manifold is a factor of a connected solvable Lie group by a lattice.
words.name: Sol manifold

words.def: Submetry a short map f between metric spaces is called a submetry if there exists R > 0 such that for any point x and radius r < R we have that image of metric r-ball is an r-ball, i.e.
words.name: Submetry

words.def:
Systole. The k-systole of M, 
  
    
      
        s
        y
        s
        
          t
          
            k
          
        
        (
        M
        )
      
    
    {\displaystyle syst_{k}(M)}
  
, is the minimal volume of k-cycle nonhomologous to zero.
words.name: Systole

words.def: Totally convex. A subset K of a Riemannian manifold M is called totally convex if for any two points in K any geodesic connecting them lies entirely in K, see also convex.
words.name: Totally convex.

words.def: Totally geodesic submanifold is a submanifold such that all geodesics in the submanifold are also geodesics of the surrounding manifold.
words.name: Totally geodesic

words.def: Uniquely geodesic metric space is a metric space where any two points are the endpoints of a unique minimizing geodesic.
words.name: Uniquely geodesic metric space

words.def: Word metric on a group is a metric of the Cayley graph constructed using a set of generators.
words.name: Word metric
